author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request met all of the guidelines for auto-merging and is scheduled to be merged when the mandatory waiting period (3 days) has elapsed.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have read the package naming guidelines: https://pkgdocs.julialang.org/v1/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment. You can edit blocking comments, adding `[noblock]` to them in order to unblock auto-merging.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->

This is only barely less empty than the previous registration at https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/108582. Please don't try to register this package again until it is a little bit more mature. See [Should I register my package now?](https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General?tab=readme-ov-file#should-i-register-my-package-now):

> If your package is at a stage where it might be useful to others, or provide functionality other packages in General might want to rely on

I don't think this is yet at a stage where others can use it in any meaningful way. There should be more functionality, and - very importantly - there has to be some form of documentation. [At the very least](https://discourse.julialang.org/t/when-does-it-make-sense-to-post-a-new-package-to-the-julia-repository/108701/4), that would be a description of the package's purpose and a small usage example in the README.

Note that package registration isn't really necessary until there are other registered packages that should use this package as a dependency. I realize that "unregistered" packages make some development workflows more difficult. For that, I would recommend that you look at [LocalRegistry](https://github.com/GunnarFarneback/LocalRegistry.jl). Setting up your own development registry also takes care of any issues you might have with this package being a dependency of other *unregistered* packages or projects.

This pull request has been inactive for 30 days and will be automatically closed 7 days from now. If this pull request should not be closed, please either (1) fix the AutoMerge issues and re-trigger Registrator, which will automatically update the pull request, or (2) post a comment explaining why you would like this pull request to be manually merged. [noblock]
This pull request has been inactive for more than 30 days and has automatically been closed. Feel free to register your package or version again once you fix the AutoMerge issues. [noblock]
